pullRequest.body:
Prove isNilpotent_of_le for LieSubmodules
---
I am working on defining the largest nilpotent ideal of a Lie algebra within the framework:
https://github.com/orgs/leanprover-community/projects/17
A somewhat similar object, namely the radical of a Lie algebra (the largest solvable ideal), is already defined in [Algebra/Lie/Solvable.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Solvable.lean).

In this PR, I prove that if M_1, M_2 are LieSubmodules with M_1 <= M_2 and M_2 is nilpotent, then M_1 is also nilpotent. To establish this, I introduce a new theorem in the Morphisms namespace:
Function.Injective.lieModuleIsNilpotent
This serves as the injective counterpart to the existing theorem:
Function.Surjective.lieModuleIsNilpotent

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

@jano-wol Thanks for addressing my suggestions. I won't be able to review again till this evening but since you have addressed all my remarks, you should feel free to remove the "awaiting-author" tag. That way your PR becomes visible in the review queue again.
@ocfnash Thx, I removed the flag.

:v: jano-wol can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13399554505/job/37426837184)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13399554505/job/37426837477)

I've left a final nitpicks.

Once you've applied these, please feel free to merge!

bors d+

Thanks, I've left some review, mostly nitpicks.

I'll review again once you've had a chance to look at these suggestions.

I've left a final nitpicks.

Once you've applied these, please feel free to merge!

bors d+

I think we should delay introducing the hypothesis `hf` and `hg` since they are not used yet
```suggestion
variable {f : L R L} {g : M [R] M} (hfg :  x m, f x, g m = g x, m)
```
(this will reorder arguments in some lemmas, so you will have to adjust the code where you use them, but this should not present any problems)
Fixed.

You're not actually using this so it can go:
```suggestion
```
(I'd guess you were in a previous version)
Fixed.

When line length forces a new line, it's usually best to avoid having it inside a term. If we drop the type ascription on the RHS (since Lean is smart enough to infer it) then we can do:
```suggestion
theorem lieModule_lcs_map_le (k : ) :
    (lowerCentralSeries R L M k : Submodule R M).map g  lowerCentralSeries R L M k := by
```

Incidentally this lemma proves half of `Function.Surjective.lieModule_lcs_map_eq` below.

If you like (but only if you want to) you can golf the proof of `Function.Surjective.lieModule_lcs_map_eq` by starting at line 1 with:
```lean
refine le_antisymm (lieModule_lcs_map_le hfg k) ?_
```
Correct point, so I started to rely on lieModule_lcs_map_le in lieModule_lcs_map_eq.

If `foo` is a rewriting lemma, then writing `apply foo.mpr` is (essentially) the same as `rw [foo]` and this is preferred, so:
```suggestion
    rw [lowerCentralSeries_succ, LieSubmodule.lieIdeal_oper_eq_linear_span', Submodule.map_span,
      Submodule.span_le]
```
Fixed. Thanks for the explanation!

This is a non-terminal (i.e., not goal-closing) `simp` and we [do not allow these](https://leanprover-community.github.io/extras/simp.html#non-terminal-simps) as they make for brittle proofs.
```suggestion
    simp only [lowerCentralSeries_succ, SetLike.mem_coe, LieSubmodule.mem_toSubmodule]
```
In this case no additional lemmas were being picked up beyond those listed so inserting the word `only` (as above) is sufficient but in general you have to "squeeze" the `simp` by using the interactive `simp?`.
Oh I missed that simp, thx for pointing it out. Fixed.

```suggestion
variable (hg_inj : Injective g) [LieModule R L M]
```
Fixed.

```suggestion
  simpa [LieSubmodule.bot_toSubmodule, le_bot_iff, Submodule.map_bot]

variable (hf : Surjective f) (hg : Surjective g)
```
Fixed.

No action required since you have chosen the right name but I just wanted to comment that you have been forced to use a fairly bad name for consistency with what already exists. Some day we should improve the naming in this (very old) code.
I see, OK!
Non-terminal `simp`
Fixed

```suggestion
      simp [hfg x m_n, h]
```
(the other two lemmas carry `@[simp]` attributes so they will be automatically included)

```suggestion
     simp
```
(as above)

```suggestion
variable [LieModule R L M] (hg_inj : Injective g)
```

```suggestion
  simpa [hk] using lieModule_lcs_map_le hfg k
```

```suggestion
      refine Submodule.span_mono (Set.Subset.trans ?_ this)
```

No need for `section`
```suggestion
variable (R L M)
variable [LieModule R L M]
```
(you'll need to drop the corresponding `end` later on)

Sometimes `aesop` can be slow but it will crush goals like this efficiently so we should use it:
```suggestion
  let f : L R L := LieHom.id
  let g : M [R] M := Submodule.inclusion h
  have hfg :  x m, f x, g m = g x, m := by aesop
  exact (Submodule.inclusion_injective h).lieModuleIsNilpotent hfg
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Algebra/Algebra/Lie): isNilpotent_of_le for LieSubmodules
